origination.corpname: University of Michigan. Executive Vice-President and Chief Financial Officer.

did.unittitle: Executive Vice-President and Chief Financial Officer (University of Michigan) publications 1917-2015, 1952-2013
did.abstract: Executive Vice-President and Chief Financial Officer publications includes the general university budgets in addition to budgets for the University Hospital and the residence halls. Also contains appropriation requests, audit reports, capital outlay reports, and department payrolls and accounts. Also includes financial reports and reports of investments.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

did.physloc: Portions located in offsite storage; prior notification required for access.

acqinfo.p: Publications are received periodically from the unit (donor no. 11260)

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records expected.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Executive Vice-President and Chief Financial Officer (University of Michigan) publications, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Please consult the history found in the finding aid for Executive Vice-President and Chief Financial Officer (University of Michigan) Records.

scopecontent.p: The Publications series of the Vice President and Chief Financial Officer is divided into two subseries: Unit Publications and Sub-Unit Publications. The Unit Publications subseries is divided into Budgets and Reports. The publications includes the general university budgets in addition to budgets for the University Hospital and the residence halls as well as appropriation requests, audit reports, capital outlay reports, and department payrolls and accounts. Also included are financial reports and reports of investments.

did.unittitle: Unit Publications
Budgets

scopecontent.p: The need for multiple copies led university officials in 1919/20 to print copies of most of the budget. Between 1919/20 and 1947/48 this bound record was divided into two parts. Part I Summary of the Budget, gave a quick overview of university general fund spending. Part II, Salary Budget, detailed the largest item in the general fund budget. The Salary Budget omitted, however, all non-salary expenses and the optional explanation of changes.

In 1948/49 the printed budget was modified. The Salary Budget was retitled Detailed Budget and its scope was broadened. Non-salary items previously excluded, such as "Current Expense and Equipment" and "Travel" were reported, as well as a few general fund accounts which earlier had not been detailed. A growing concern over the privacy of individual salary figures, led to a major revision in the budget's format in 1956/57. The Summary Budget, for convenience long published as a separate document, became the only published document.

In place of the Detailed Budget a new publication, called Department Payroll and Accounts, appeared. This document, which had only a limited distribution, included the salary information formerly printed in section II. This salary information also appears in the pages of the Michigan Daily which, based upon legislation enacted in October 1979 defined state employees' salaries as public records, has annually published the salaries of faculty and professional and administrative employees of the university. In university records salary information, dating from 1956 through 1971, will be found under the heading "Reports" under the title Departmental Payroll and Accounts. They include a list of all employees arranged by department and their salaries. These reports also note faculty sabbaticals and leaves. For later salary lists the researcher should consult the finding aid for: University of Michigan. Office of Human Resources and Affirmative Action. Publications.

In 1957/58, although the Summary Budget continued to be published, a more complete publication Proposed Budget and Supplementary Schedules was begun. It included the information found in the general fund budget, as well as information about project budgets. This new publication, referred to informally as "the grey book" because of its cover, became the basic budgetary reference tool. In 1965/66 the volume's title was changed to Budget and Supplementary Schedules. In 1967/68 it became known by the simple title, Budgets. In 1973/74 the grey book was divided into four volumes, one subtitled "All Campus," the other three giving the budget for each of the university's three major centers, Ann Arbor, Dearborn, and Flint. The general university budgets are arranged chronologically beginning in 1920 through the present.

Compared with the complexity of the publications reflecting the university's annual general fund budget, the Trust Fund Budget is simple. There are several volumes for the period from 1948/49 through 1967/68 in the PUBLICATIONS series. This, however, is not a complete run. The manuscript Trust Fund Budgets are found in boxes 34-50 of the manuscript records of the University of Michigan Vice President and Chief Financial Officer and should be consulted for more complete information.

The budgets of the residence halls and University Hospital have been retained because they are the university's largest auxiliary activities. The hospital, for example, usually accounts for twenty to twenty-five percent of the university's total income and expenses. They are similar in form to the printed annual budget's Detailed Section. The hospital budget contains primarily salary information and also a few general financial tables. It seems to have been modeled on the older official copy of the university budget.

Reports

scopecontent.p: Reports include appropriation requests, audits, and capital outlay reports prepared by the vice president for transmission to the state government, primarily to the legislature. Other reports include: Commitments, Frequency Distribution of Commitments, and Flexible Funds Balance Estimate; Departmental Payrolls and Accounts (General Fund and Auxiliary activities); Financial Information Detail by Account; and most important, the annual financial report.

The Appropriation Requests date from 1948 to 1973. They are arranged chronologically under a variety of titles. These reports were sent to the state legislature requesting funds for the operation of the university and are filled with information regarding the financial needs of the university and the plans of the administration to fulfill the goals of the university. Appropriations Requests, 1967-1973 contain requests for state appropriations, as approved by the Regents for 1967, 1968 and 1969 as well as requests for special appropriations for the Medical School and the Institute for Gerontology.

There are only scattered audit reports for the university as a whole. They are arranged alphabetically by title. However, there are several financial statements and audit reports for specific units. These reports are arranged alphabetically under the unit.

The capital outlay reports are arranged chronologically under various titles. Mandated by Public Act no. 116 of 1953, they include not only the annual capital outlay report, but also long-range planning for the upcoming five-year period. These reports begin in 1953 and continue through 1974-1975. Beginning in 1970-1971 there are separate volumes for the Ann Arbor, Dearborn, and Flint campuses.

Originally prepared for the regents' scrutiny, today the annual financial reports are the basic documents through which the university makes itself accountable for the receipt and expenditure of funds. Two types are generated: Financial (originally Treasurer's) and Investment. The Financial Report, and its predecessor Treasurer's Report, has been issued annually since 1883. For earlier Treasurer's Report the researcher should consult the finding aid for: University of Michigan. Treasurer. Publications.

The annual financial reports are arranged chronologically dating from 1917 through the present. Their titles vary. The later financial reports include a Report of Independent Auditors. Originally, the financial report was one volume. In 1975 the Financial Report was published in two parts. The first offers a cursory overview of all university income and expenses regardless of the source. The second presents tables detailing income and expenses at the unit level. Because the Financial Report includes both general fund and project income and details both summary salary and non-salary expenses, it is the single most comprehensive document available regarding university finances.

Sub-Unit Publications

scopecontent.p: Sub-Unit Publications include reports from the Investment Office and budget analyses from the Office of Financial Analysis and Cost Reimbursement.

The Investment Report is a highly specialized document which annually details where the university has placed the funds available to it. Begun in 1928 the Investment Report provides a detailed list of all investments the University of Michigan made and the value of those investments. In the mid-1960s the basic structure of the document was changed. Individual accounts were no longer listed. Instead, the university's investment portfolio was reported on as a whole, although the practice of citing each investment instrument by name was retained. The new format made it clear how university funds as a whole were invested, but made it impossible to determine where the funds of a particular account were placed. The Schedule of Investments covers the period from 1968 through 1989. It provides a detailed list of the University of Michigan's investments including the names of companies and the book and market values of the university's various investments.
